case_name: State of Assam v. Ranga Mahammad

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1367 and 1368 of 1966 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTIONCivil Appeals Nos.1367 and 1368 of 1966. Appeals from the judgment and order dated April 19, 1966 of the

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and order dated April 19, 1966 of the Assam High Court in Civil Rules Nos. 171 and 236 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated April 19, 1966 of the Assam High Court in Civil Rules Nos. 171 and 236 of 1965. Purshottam Trikamdas, A. K. Sen, Naunit Lal and Vineet Kumar,for the

facts.text: Ranga Mahammad filed two writ petitions against D. N. Deka and B. N. Sarma questioning transfer of Deka from Jorhat to Gauhati and appointment and posting of Sarma at Jorhat.

anchor.surface_text: These are two appeals by certificate against a common judgment of the High Court of Assam Nagaland at Gauhati, dismissing two writ petitions filed by one Ranga Mahammad against D. N. Deka and B. N. Sarma, District Sessions Judges respectively of Lower and Upper Assam Districts questioning the transfer of the former from Jorhat to Gauhati and the appointment and posting of the latter at Jorhat.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the writ petitions but held that there was no consultation with regard to posting of Deka and transfers were irregular.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner had asked that the relevant notifications by the Government be quashed on the ground that the High Court alone could make the transfers and, in any event, the High Court had to be consulted and was not consulted before making the orders. The petitions were heard and disposed of by a Divisional Bench consisting of Chief Justice Mehrotra and Mr. Justice S. K. Dutta. The Chief Justice held that there was no consultation with regard to the posting of Deka, that the transfer of Deka to Gauhati was irregular as the High Court alone could have ordered it, and that the transfer of B. N. Sarma was for a like reason also irregular.

facts.text: High Court declined writ of quo warranto as none of the District Judges could be said to occupy wrongly the office.

anchor.surface_text: Holding, however, that none of the District Judges could be said to occupy wrongly the office of District Sessions Judge the High Court declined the writ of quo warranto. The petitions ,were accordingly dismissed but without costs to the State Government.

facts.text: Mr. Justice Dutta passed remarks describing Government action as mala fide and actuated by ulterior motive.

anchor.surface_text: In a separate but concurring judgment Dutta J. passed some scathing remarks on the action of the Government which he described as mala fide and actuated by some ulterior motive.

facts.text: State Government obtained certificates under Art. 132 on ground of interpretation of Arts. 233 and 235.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on being moved by the State Government granted certificates under Art. 132 of the Constitution on the ground that the judgment involved the interpretation of Arts. 233 and 235 of the Constitution.

facts.text: State of Assam consists of three Sessions Divisions: Upper Assam Districts (Jorhat), Lower Assam Districts (Gauhati), Cachar Districts (Silchar).

anchor.surface_text: The State of Assam consists of only three Sessions Divisions. They are The Upper Assam Districts, the Lower Assam Districts and the Cachar Districts with Jorhat, Gauhati and Silchar respectively as the Headquarters of the three District Judges.

facts.text: On December 6, 1962, Chief Justice appointed A. Rahman, District Judge Gauhati, as Registrar and recommended D. N. Sarma as District Judge Gauhati and D. C. Sharma as Additional District Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: On December 6, 1962 the Chief Justice appointed A. Rahman, District Judge, Gauhati, as Registrar and recommended that D. N. Sarma, Additional District Sessions Judge be promoted and appointed District Judge, Gauhati, and in B. N. Sarmas place D. C. Sharma should be appointed as Additional District Sessions Judge. This proposal was accepted by Government.

facts.text: Medhi, District Judge, was retiring creating a vacancy.

anchor.surface_text: It appears, however, that one Medhi, District Judge, was retiring and there was a vacancy.

facts.text: There was telephone conversation between Chief Justice and Finance Minister regarding C. Choudhury for officiation in vacancy.

anchor.surface_text: It also appears from the correspondence which has been placed in our hands that there was some conversation on the telephone between the Chief Justice and the Finance Minister regarding C. Choudhury  Joint Secretary Legal Department  whom the Minister suggested for officiation in that vacancy and the Chief Justice expressed his willingness to receive him.

facts.text: On January 5, 1963, Chief Justice wrote D.O. letter stating rules do not permit appointing Choudhury.

anchor.surface_text: Later by a D. O. letter of January 5, 1963 the Chief Justice pointed out that the Rules did not permit this to be done.

facts.text: On February 7, 1963, Chief Justice recommended D. N. Deka for promotion as District Judge at Jorhat.

anchor.surface_text: He enquired why Rahman was not released although it had no connection with the other matter and the appointment of the Registrar was entirely ,a matter for the Chief Justice. He requested that Rahman be released soon and recommended the appointment of B. N. Sarma as District Judge in his place. He also suggested S. C. Baruas transfer from Cachar to Gauhati. In the vacancy of Medhi he recommended D. N. Dekas promotion and recommended his -transfer to Jorhat.

facts.text: Notification issued on June 22, 1963 appointing D. N. Deka as District Judge with headquarters at Jorhat.

anchor.surface_text: A notification was issued on June 22, 1963 -appointing Deka as District Judge with Headquarters at Jorhat.

facts.text: On September 7, 1963, Secretary to Government proposed transfer of B. N. Sarma to Jorhat and Deka to Gauhati.

anchor.surface_text: On September 7, 1963, this is to say, exactly seven months after the ,last letter of the Chief Justice, the Secretary to the Government of Assam wrote to the Registrar that the State Government after careful consideration could not accept the suggestion about the transfer -of Barua and proposed the transfer of B. N. Sarma to Jorhat and of Deka to Gauhati immediately as Jorhat was without a District Judge for months.

facts.text: On January 22, 1964, Registrar wrote that B. N. Sarma should go to Silchar, Barua to Jorhat, Deka to Gauhati.

anchor.surface_text: On January 22, 1964 the Registrar of the High Court wrote to say that B. N. Sarma should go to Silchar, Barua to Jorhat and Deka to Gauhati.

facts.text: On February 19, 1964, Government issued notifications transferring Deka to Gauhati and Sarma to Jorhat.

anchor.surface_text: To this a final reply was given by the Government on February 19, 1964 informing the High Court that the recommendations were not acceptable except as to Dekas transfer from Jorhat to Gauhati. B. N. Sarma was accordingly transferred to Jorhat leaving Barua where he was Notifications transferring Deka and Sarma were issued the same day.

facts.text: Ranga Mahammad filed two petitions under Arts. 226 and 227 questioning jurisdiction of Deka at Jorhat and transfer of Sarma to Jorhat, averring no consultation for Deka's appointment and posting at Gauhati.

anchor.surface_text: One Ranga Mahammad of Gauhati then filed two petitions in the High Court of Assam under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution questioning the jurisdiction of Deka, District Sessions Judge, Jorhat. He averred that the High Court was not consulted regarding Dekas appointment and posting at Gauhati. By the second petition he questioned the transfer of B. N. Sarma to Jorhat.

facts.text: Government claimed it had consulted High Court and acted within powers.

anchor.surface_text: On rule being issued in the two petitions, Government put in a detailed return pointing out that it had acted within its powers and had also consulted the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that power to transfer District Judges vests in High Court under Art. 235, not Governor under Art. 233.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was thus right in its conclusion that the powers of the Governor cease after he has appointed or promoted a person to be a district Judge and assigned him to a post in cadre. Thereafter, transfer of incumbents is a matter within the control of District Courts including the control of persons presiding there as explained in the cited case.

facts.text: Supreme Court held there was consultation before D. N. Deka was promoted and posted as District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: On this part of the case it is sufficient to say that there was consultation.

facts.text: Supreme Court declined to expunge remarks of Mr. Justice Dutta.

anchor.surface_text: Although we think that Mr. Justice Dutta need not have made the remarks we cannot say that in making them he acted with such impropriety that the extraordinary powers should be exercised.

arguments.claim: Expunction of remarks only for clear impropriety

anchor.surface_text: The power to expunge is an extraordinary power and can be exercised only when a clear case is made out.

holdings.text: The power to transfer District Judges already appointed, promoted and posted to the cadre is vested exclusively in the High Court under Article 235 and not in the Governor under Article 233.

anchor.surface_text: It follows, therefore, that under Art. 233, the Governor is only concerned with the appointment, promotion and posting to the cadre of district Judges but not with the transfer of district Judges already appointed or promoted and posted to the cadre. The latter is obviously a matter of control of district Judges which is vested in the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation: 'posting' in Art 233 associated with appointment/promotion means initial cadre assignment (noscitur a sociis); transfer is subsequent control under Art 235; supported by Arts 234-235 structure, policy, and precedents like Nripendranath Bagchi.

holdings.text: The High Court was right that powers of Governor cease after appointment/promotion/posting; thereafter transfer is within High Court control over district courts.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was thus right in its conclusion that the powers of the Governor cease after he has appointed or promoted a person to be a district Judge and assigned him to a post in cadre. Thereafter, transfer of incumbents is a matter within the control of District Courts including the control of persons presiding there as explained in the cited case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court's view based on constitutional scheme limiting Governor to initial steps; transfer part of comprehensive HC control.

holdings.text: Consultation with High Court under Articles 233 and 235 for appointment/promotion/posting of District Judges is mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: That such a consultation is mandatory has been laid down quite definitely in the recent decision of this Court in Chandra Mohan v. U. P. On this part of the case it is sufficient to say that there was consultation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedent in Chandra Mohan v. U.P. that consultation requirement is mandatory, not directory.

holdings.text: There was consultation with the High Court before D. N. Deka was promoted and posted as District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: On this part of the case it is sufficient to say that there was consultation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court reviewed facts/correspondence and found sufficient consultation occurred prior to promotion/posting.

holdings.text: The remarks of Mr. Justice Dutta should not be expunged.

anchor.surface_text: Although we think that Mr. Justice Dutta need not have made the remarks we cannot say that in making them he acted with such impropriety that the extraordinary powers should be exercised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extraordinary power to expunge exercised only for clear impropriety; remarks unnecessary but not improper enough.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was thus right in its conclusion that the powers of the Governor cease after he has appointed or promoted a person to be a district Judge and assigned him to a post in cadre. Thereafter, transfer of incumbents is a matter within the control of District Courts including the control of persons presiding there as explained in the cited case. As the High Court is the authority to make transfers, there was no question of a consultation on this account. The State Government was not the authority to order the transfers.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court correct that State Government lacks power to transfer District Judges; consultation occurred for promotion and posting; remarks of Justice Dutta not expunged

anchor.surface_text: It follows, therefore, that under Art. 233, the Governor is only concerned with the appointment, promotion and posting to the cadre of district Judges but not with the transfer of district Judges already appointed or promoted and posted to the cadre. The latter is obviously a matter of control of district Judges which is vested in the High Court.

The High Court was thus right in its conclusion that the powers of the Governor cease after he has appointed or promoted a person to be a district Judge and assigned him to a post in cadre. Thereafter, transfer of incumbents is a matter within the control of District Courts including the control of persons presiding there as explained in the cited case. As the High Court is the authority to make transfers, there was no question of a consultation on this account. The State Government was not the authority to order the transfers.

edges.explanation: Holding resolves the issue by confirming transfer under High Court control post initial posting

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was thus right in its conclusion that the powers of the Governor cease after he has appointed or promoted a person to be a district Judge and assigned him to a post in cadre. Thereafter, transfer of incumbents is a matter within the control of District Courts including the control of persons presiding there as explained in the cited case.

The High Court was thus right in its conclusion that the powers of the Governor cease after he has appointed or promoted a person to be a district Judge and assigned him to a post in cadre. Thereafter, transfer of incumbents is a matter within the control of District Courts including the control of persons presiding there as explained in the cited case. As the High Court is the authority to make transfers, there was no question of a consultation on this account. The State Government was not the authority to order the transfers.

anchor.surface_text: That such a consultation is mandatory has been laid down quite definitely in the recent decision of this Court in Chandra Mohan v. U. P. On this part of the case it is sufficient to say that there was consultation.

The High Court was thus right in its conclusion that the powers of the Governor cease after he has appointed or promoted a person to be a district Judge and assigned him to a post in cadre. Thereafter, transfer of incumbents is a matter within the control of District Courts including the control of persons presiding there as explained in the cited case. As the High Court is the authority to make transfers, there was no question of a consultation on this account. The State Government was not the authority to order the transfers.

anchor.surface_text: Although we think that Mr. Justice Dutta need not have made the remarks we cannot say that in making them he acted with such impropriety that the extraordinary powers should be exercised.

The High Court was thus right in its conclusion that the powers of the Governor cease after he has appointed or promoted a person to be a district Judge and assigned him to a post in cadre. Thereafter, transfer of incumbents is a matter within the control of District Courts including the control of persons presiding there as explained in the cited case. As the High Court is the authority to make transfers, there was no question of a consultation on this account. The State Government was not the authority to order the transfers.
